content:
Let D:J→[Cop,Set]D:J \to [C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}]D:J→[Cop,Set] be a JJJ-shaped diagram of presheavevs, where JJJ is a small category. And let us assume that we have a cone under DDD with tip X:Cop→SetX:C^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{Set}X:Cop→Set.

Intuitively, for each c∈Copc \in C^{\mathrm{op}}c∈Cop, we can evaluate our diagram DDD at ccc, and get a diagram in Set\mathsf{Set}Set. So we should have some functor Dt:Cop→[J,Set]D^t:C^{\mathrm{op}} \to [J, \mathsf{Set}]Dt:Cop→[J,Set]. Similarly, by evaluating our cone at any ccc we get a cone under Dt(c)D^t(c)Dt(c) with tip X(c)X(c)X(c). So we have a bunch of related cones.

I suspect that we can organize the tips of these cones using a functor X′:Cop→[J,Set]X':C^{\mathrm{op}} \to [J, \mathsf{Set}]X′:Cop→[J,Set]. This functor acts on objects by sending ccc to the JJJ-shaped diagram constant at X(c)X(c)X(c).

Can we form a natural transformation from DtD^tDt to X′X'X′?
(For context, if this works out as I hope, I'll be able to finish showing how we can take a colimit of a diagram of presheaves!)

Perhaps a simpler way to ask this question is this:

We have a bijection Cat(J,[Cop,Set])≅Cat(J×Cop,Set)\mathsf{Cat}(J, [C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}]) \cong \mathsf{Cat}(J \times C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set})Cat(J,[Cop,Set])≅Cat(J×Cop,Set). Can this bijection be upgraded to an isomorphism or equivalence of functor categories?

If this can be upgraded to an isomorphism or equivalence of categories, then I can hope for the existence of a functor F:Cat(J,[Cop,Set])→Cat(J×Cop,Set)→Cat(Cop×J,Set)→Cat(Cop,[J,Set])F:\mathsf{Cat}(J, [C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}]) \to \mathsf{Cat}(J \times C^{\mathrm{op}}, \mathsf{Set}) \to \mathsf{Cat}(C^{\mathrm{op}} \times J, \mathsf{Set}) \to \mathsf{Cat}(C^{\mathrm{op}}, [J, \mathsf{Set}])F:Cat(J,[Cop,Set])→Cat(J×Cop,Set)→Cat(Cop×J,Set)→Cat(Cop,[J,Set]) that is witness to an isomorphism or equivalence.

Hint: show that, for any closed monoidal category, there is an isomorphism [X⊗Y,Z]≅[X,[Y,Z]][X \otimes Y, Z] \cong [X, [Y, Z]][X⊗Y,Z]≅[X,[Y,Z]], i.e. the "external" tensor-hom adjunction can be represented "internally".

Thanks for the hint! I was just noticing Proposition 3.1 in this nlab article, which I think covers this point. Maybe I'll give a try at proving the statement you just gave though, before reading the nLab proof!

A cone under DDD with tip XXX can be described as a family of morphisms

ιjc:D(j)(c)→X(c)\iota_{jc} : D(j)(c) \to X(c)ιjc​:D(j)(c)→X(c)

It is natural in ccc, meaning that that for every fixed jjj, the sub-family (ιjc)c(\iota_{jc})_c(ιjc​)c​ is a natural transformation from D(j)D(j)D(j) to XXX.

It is also natural in jjj, meaning that for every fixed ccc, the sub-family μc=(ιjc)j\mu_c = (\iota_{jc})_jμc​=(ιjc​)j​ is a natural transformation from D(_)(c)=Dt(c)D(\_)(c) = D^t(c)D(_)(c)=Dt(c) to the constant functor X′(c)X'(c)X′(c) on JJJ with value X(c)X(c)X(c).

To answer your first question, I think the family μ=(μc)c\mu = (\mu_c)_cμ=(μc​)c​ defines a natural transformation from DtD^t Dt to X′X'X′.

Thanks @Peva Blanchard ! Thanks to the comments in this thread, I now have two promising approaches for solving my problem, instead of zero :tada:! I'll plan to work on exploring these approaches tomorrow.

So the natural transformation amounts to the commutativity of this diagram
image.png

Unfolding the fact these arrows are natural transformations, we obtain the diagrams
image.png

David Egolf said:

Thanks Peva Blanchard !

you welcome :smile:
I've made some good progress on understanding this stuff today, but I'm not quite ready to type up here what I have. Hopefully I'll get there soon!

I think I now understand Peva Blanchard's argument - I worked out all the details to my satisfaction. My plan now is to: (1) return to the other thread and finish off this puzzle, and then (2) return here and think about Nathanael Arkor's hint.
